ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One socially distacned in person coffee meet up

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a great discussion-based course that allowed for a lot of flexibility and engagement. I learned about various aspects of inequality in China but the course went far beyond that. We covered social, cultural, and political factors that are highly relevant to understanding China today.

I developed a broad knowledge of many aspects of Chinese culture and life, ranging from the economy to marriage. I feel that I now understand how China works a lot better. I also gained a lot of insight into the Chinese government by participating in the two debates throughout the semester, one of which involve role-playing as government officials.

I gained a lot of insight into China's current state as influenced by rapid social and economic changes. The content that this course provided was very interrelated and I felt like I got a taste of a wide array of topics pertaining to social inequality in China.
I gained critical analysis skills, qualitative analysis skills, and a new outlook on Chinese society.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class covered a number of topics which was really great and the student presentations mixed things up every week. More videos would've been good because they really highlighted a lot of the current issues in a real way

I really enjoyed that this course was such a small seminar. Because of that, each class felt like an open discussion with Professor Zang. I think this also meant that there was a universal level of participation which included doing the reading. One of the strengths of this course were the readings, which were obviously carefully chosen and quite interesting. Another strength was the atmosphere of the class fostered by Professor Zang, who emphasized understanding the material and intellectual curiosity over memorizing stuff for tests. I think the greatest strength of this course were the debates included in the syllabus, which were not only very fun but very informative.

Strengths: The small class size created a discussion-led learning atmosphere that is very conducive to critical thinking. You learn about many different topics which give you a broad perspective of China's current condition. Weakness: The prompts for the papers are really vague and did not provide a lot of instruction or a rubric. Although the grading was very reasonable, sometimes it was hard to direct a paper or know what the professor was looking for without much guidance.
This course is fantastic and I just wish there were a few more people in it to add even more perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Discussion was good for virtual learning so that there could be more engagement. Long lectures were less successful.

I believe that this course largely avoided many of the issues faced by classes during COVID due to its small size and also high participation. My only suggestion would be to offer section on a weekly rather than biweekly basis.

Overall, the live synchronous lecture/discussion style of this course helped make the class engaging and interesting. The student-led discussions (by a different student each week) added a refreshing touch to each week.
The class was flawless over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Take this course if you want to strengthen your understanding of socioeconomic and political aspects of Chinese society. You'll also get to pursue and interview and research project, both of which I found to be super rewarding. It's also a great class to meet other students and become good friends with them.

Yes definitely. I believe the course will be different with more students but still 100% worth taking. The structure of the work is really nice in that you work on an interview project all semester and then have a final paper on a topic of your choice.

Absolutely! China's indisputable dominance in today's global economy and relevance in most current affairs makes this course especially important in revealing the high social costs that come with rapid economic development. Every story of success has an ugly side. In order to gain a full picture of China's current state, it is crucial to recognize China's economic success with context to the many entrenched social issues seen across China at both cultural and insitutional levels.

Without question, this was my favorite class this semester. I learned a ton about Chinese society, structurally and qualitatively. If you have any interest in Chinese history, society, and economics, this class is for you. I highly recommend.
